Posts.Content: wtdedula ... I really do like my URO, and the RO I saw yesterday I liked too. What stood out with my RO yesterday is that he agreed that I should get all the information I could from the other RO and two surgeons I am scheduled to see in order for me to figure out the best treatment plan for myself. Yesterday's RO was factual and to the point sharing his opinion with confidence and never gave me the impression it was his way or the highway. In addition to my diet from my URO ... I really need to give credit to my wife (of 35+ years) who is well read, informed and supportive of what is good for me with my diet and supplements. My wife allows me to veer a little off course for my mental health then nudges me back in line (nudge = kick in the ass). Blessings of being married to an Irish Newfie woman.

Posts.Title: To eat or not to eat some things...

Posts.Content: When I was recently DX my URO said to cut out red meat, dairy and follow a veggie based diet ... allowing for occasional wild salmon. I cut out as much sugar products such as any sweets, pastas, breads and alcohol (though fudge with two or three small glasses of red wine a week). Breakfast is the only time a have a little dairy having cottage cheese with flax oil, medley of fresh fruit, dash of cinnamon and walnuts. Lunch is a variety of fresh vegetables with avocado oil, vinegar and tumeric. Dinner is mainly veggies with occasional small amount of meat. The other night I had a homemade tomato sauce over spaghetti squash with two very small meatballs (wife and daughter had pasta with a side of squash) along with a garden salad. Once a week have a boiled egg as a snack. Dessert is usually a big spoonful of almond butter with chopped almonds and a glass of almond or coconut milk. Beverages is copious amount of coffee in the morning with water throughout the day. Once a week is cheat night. This Sunday it will be take out Chinese food. Really needed to get on this diet as want to drop another 10 lbs to run (slow run) a 12k on May 5th.

Posts.Content: I am a newbie too with my DX just a week ago on Feb 5th. There is a lot to learn, and I am still learning. This forum has been very helpful to me as well as two books: Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer by Dr Walsh and The Key to Prostate Cancer by Dr Scholz (that I just received in the mail today). Posts.Title: Newbie to the forum

Posts.Content: My instructions were to start kegels one week after catheter is out (about two weeks post surgery). I went back to work part time (field work ... walking, some standing, riding in truck) one week after the catheter was out. On the days I am home I average 3 to 4 pads per day though on a couple occasions at home went through as many as 5 to 7 pads as I was over active. On the days I work the average is 4 to 5 pads per day. I do wear the diaper as a back up during the day and night, but only need to swap out the pads. Easy to do at work whether in the bathroom or if in the field just takes a few seconds to step around the truck and pull out the old pad and slide in a new one. The old one goes into a plastic veggie bag to dump later. Actually pretty easy and no big deal. I took the advise the other day from this forum practicing my kegels by starting, then stopping, my stream numerous times when peeing. I can actually stop the stream, relax keeping the stream stopped, and starting it again on my terms.

Posts.Title: Update ... thoughts appreciated.

Posts.Content: Week ago met with RO #1. Scheduled for a one hour appointment that barely lasted 20 minutes stating in short that best course of treatment was RT consisting of EBRT + seeds + ADT ... that surgery would not be a good option (citing numerous medicals stats from 2000 - 2013). Left the appointment with a gut feeling something did not sit well. Today met with surgeon #1. Personable and the appointment went at least 1 1/2 hours ... plus another hour with other medical staff setting up a surgery date for March 26th (to lock in a date). Saying this as surgeon #2 (shared this info with surgeon #1) who I have an appt with in two weeks, called me up at home two nights ago at 7:30p to say he looked at my file and said I was a candidate for surgery. Surgeon #1 has over 1700 robotic surgeries under his belt (and has been mentioned favorably on this site) and surgeon #2 has over 3000 robotic surgeries as well as being a prostate cancer patient himself who underwent robotic surgery. Surgeon #2 asked that I call him tomorrow Thursday after I met with surgeon #1 today. Both surgeons know each other and surgeon #1 joked that surgeon #2 is going to try and convince me to have him (surgeon #2) perform the surgery. Here is my dilemma ... after much research and discussion my wife and I have decided to do the surgery first followed by RT and ADT if needed. Since my cancer is aggressive surgery sooner than later is better. Wife has a point that surgeon #2 is very experienced ( and one of top five in the nation, as well as travels to perform the surgery ) plus he as walked in our shoes before and understands that it is like to be the patient ... that he should be the surgeon I select. Having been married to her for nearly four decades I find it hard to argue with her on this point. Even if I have to wait a couple months for the surgery I am still good to go. What you guys think ?

Posts.Title: Update ... thoughts appreciated.

Posts.Content: Been a crazy week or so. We decided on the surgery route for treatment and had a date with Dr Ellis setup for March 26th. On Monday night March 4th Dr Porter called me up at home saying after looking at my records he wanted to get this fixed for me. Told me to have my consultation with Dr Ellis on Wednesday the 6th and to call him back on Thursday the 7th. Dr Ellis said the earliest date he had for surgery was March 26th. On Thursday the 7th, Dr Porter said he could get me in for surgery on March 14th. Since Dr Porter was our #1 go to guy we selected the March 14th date with him. Met with Dr Porter on the 12th, prep on the 13th and surgery early morning of the 14th. Wow ... what a journey the last couple of days. Gotta say, all staff pre-op, op and post-op were amazing. The surgery was done with the newest version of the robot ... the xi. I was rolled into the operating room exactly at 0830 hours. Dr Porter was great chatting with me and assisting with moving me to the operating table. Surgery was 5 hours. The last thing I remember was being asked where I liked going on vacation, then the next was waking in recovery. I do not remember being moved from recovery to my room nor moved into my room bed. Next was seeing my wife and daughter at about 3p. Had a private room and my daughter spent the night with me. Staff was great making sure she had a sleeping cot and linens. Around 6p I took my first steps ... a total of 1/8 of a mile. (16 hallway laps to a mile). I ate a general menu dinner of meat loaf, mashed potatoes, broccoli, stewed prunes, yogurt and coffee. The dinner was taste, the coffee was not. Physically, it was hard to eat because of lack of saliva and the gas bloated pain was horrible. After dinner I walked a 1/4 mile. The next morning I was up at 6a walking alone just fine as my daughter went downstairs to get me a tall American (real coffee). We had our coffee walking a total of one mile then had a breakfast of scrambled eggs, chicken apple sausage, stewed prunes and yogurt. After breakfast walked another mile. Before lunch walked a 1/4 mile eating an Asian stir fry, white rice, stewed prunes and yogurt. After lunch walked another mile. I walked because really wanted to pass some gas to alleviate the cramping but just could not. Told I would be discharged at about 6p. At 5p walked another 1/4 mile and then prepared to be discharged learning how to change the piss bag and to have the drain in my side pulled out. Pulling that drain out was very, very unpleasant and I ended up at the end cursing with the "f-word" in front of my male nurse, wife and daughter ... they all said it as okay and understood, and gave me a little laugh for doing so. Ride home was about 30 minutes and I felt every bump in the road. Took a couple of tylenols and a stool softener. Did not feel like eating dinner, just wanted to drink water. I was able to get in and out of bed myself. Went to sleep at 8p, and up at 1a for a glass of water and another tylenol. At 5a this morning I was able to pass gas, with my wife waking up giving me a bad time about doing so. Since was awake, got up for a glass of water and a tylenol (500 mg) then into the den to watch tv. Passed more gas then fell asleep on the couch till 7a. About an hour later now sitting at the computer with a cup of coffee sharing my adventure with you all. Dr Porter saw me in my hospital room last night saying the surgery went well taking as wide of margins possible. Will have to wait till next Friday March 22nd for pathology and getting my piss tube pulled. Feeling pretty good, still passing some gas as I am typing this ... feels so good ! And ... just now my first gassy loose bowel movement. Thank goodness. Tomorrow is St Patrick's Day with corned beef and cabbage !

Posts.Title: I'm back ... ! Prostate surgery completed.

Posts.Content: Been a crazy week or so. We decided on the surgery route for treatment and had a date with Dr Ellis setup for March 26th. On Monday night March 4th Dr Porter called me up at home saying after looking at my records he wanted to get this fixed for me. Told me to have my consultation with Dr Ellis on Wednesday the 6th and to call him back on Thursday the 7th. Dr Ellis said the earliest date he had for surgery was March 26th. On Thursday the 7th, Dr Porter said he could get me in for surgery on March 14th. Since Dr Porter was our #1 go to guy we selected the March 14th date with him. Met with Dr Porter on the 12th, prep on the 13th and surgery early morning of the 14th. Wow ... what a journey the last couple of days. Gotta say, all staff pre-op, op and post-op were amazing. The surgery was done with the newest version of the robot ... the xi. I was rolled into the operating room exactly at 0830 hours. Dr Porter was great chatting with me and assisting with moving me to the operating table. Surgery was 5 hours. The last thing I remember was being asked where I liked going on vacation, then the next was waking in recovery. I do not remember being moved from recovery to my room nor moved into my room bed. Next was seeing my wife and daughter at about 3p. Had a private room and my daughter spent the night with me. Staff was great making sure she had a sleeping cot and linens. Around 6p I took my first steps ... a total of 1/8 of a mile. (16 hallway laps to a mile). I ate a general menu dinner of meat loaf, mashed potatoes, broccoli, stewed prunes, yogurt and coffee. The dinner was taste, the coffee was not. Physically, it was hard to eat because of lack of saliva and the gas bloated pain was horrible. After dinner I walked a 1/4 mile. The next morning I was up at 6a walking alone just fine as my daughter went downstairs to get me a tall American (real coffee). We had our coffee walking a total of one mile then had a breakfast of scrambled eggs, chicken apple sausage, stewed prunes and yogurt. After breakfast walked another mile. Before lunch walked a 1/4 mile eating an Asian stir fry, white rice, stewed prunes and yogurt. After lunch walked another mile. I walked because really wanted to pass some gas to alleviate the cramping but just could not. Told I would be discharged at about 6p. At 5p walked another 1/4 mile and then prepared to be discharged learning how to change the piss bag and to have the drain in my side pulled out. Pulling that drain out was very, very unpleasant and I ended up at the end cursing with the "f-word" in front of my male nurse, wife and daughter ... they all said it as okay and understood, and gave me a little laugh for doing so. Ride home was about 30 minutes and I felt every bump in the road. Took a couple of tylenols and a stool softener. Did not feel like eating dinner, just wanted to drink water. I was able to get in and out of bed myself. Went to sleep at 8p, and up at 1a for a glass of water and another tylenol. At 5a this morning I was able to pass gas, with my wife waking up giving me a bad time about doing so. Since was awake, got up for a glass of water and a tylenol (500 mg) then into the den to watch tv. Passed more gas then fell asleep on the couch till 7a. About an hour later now sitting at the computer with a cup of coffee sharing my adventure with you all. Dr Porter saw me in my hospital room last night saying the surgery went well taking as wide of margins possible. Will have to wait till next Friday March 22nd for pathology and getting my piss tube pulled. Feeling pretty good, still passing some gas as I am typing this ... feels so good ! And ... just now my first gassy loose bowel movement. Thank goodness. Tomorrow is St Patrick's Day with corned beef and cabbage !

Posts.Title: Today ... got my post-op pathology.

Posts.Content: Still collecting my data after meeting with RO #1 and still need to meet with Surgeon #1, RO #2 and Surgeon #2. RO #1 suggested treatment plan beginning with Casodex and Lupron before seed implants followed with 5 weeks of EBRT. Knowing all cases are different, research suggests radiation and ADT many times follows surgery (depending on pathology afterwards). Question: Wonder if should start the ADT segment of treatment now before the decision on the treatment plan I take ? My thinking is if more than likely will be heading down this path either way why not get a jump start on things. I will be submitting this question to my RO #1 and is also on my list for my upcoming consultations. What you guys think from your experience ?

Posts.Title: Surgery and/or Radiation ...thinking ahead planning question.

Posts.Content: Robotic xi surgery March 14th. Today catheter (bag buddy) removed and got my pathology report. Right 4 of 12 lymph nodes positive (largest 4mm). Left 1 of 8 nodes positive (largest 9mm). Prostate fat biopsy: Adipose tissue, no malignancy identified. Total Gleason score 9 (4+5). Primary pattern 4. Secondary pattern 5. Gleason 4: 65 - 70% Gleason 5: 15 - 20% Grade 5. Intraductal: present Tumor size (dominant) 4.3cm apex to base both sides. Extraprostatic extension: present right lateral, posterior and left lateral aspects apex to base and at anterior mid aspect. Urinary bladder neck invasion: not identified Seminal vesicle invasion: present Lymph-vascular invasion" present Margins involved: carcinoma unifocally extends to anterior mid margin in area of extraprostatic extension (2mm span of tumor at margin) Pathologic state pT3b pN1 Everything is still sinking in. Ultrasensitive PSA test in 6 weeks. Possible radiation or radiation/hormone in future.

Posts.Title: Two Year Update

Posts.Content: I was pretty much on what I would call a "colonoscopy cleanse" the two days before surgery. My insides were totally cleared out. I had my 5 hour surgery in the morning and was in my room in the afternoon with a short walk-about in the halls. That evening I was surprised to learn that I was on a "general diet" able to have anything I wanted. I was hungry and for my dinner chose what I felt I could eat : meatloaf, mashed potatoes, broccoli, stewed prunes, yogurt and coffee (yuck blah). I ate most of it and felt good with another walk after dinner. The next morning I had scrambled eggs, chicken/apple sausage, stewed prunes and yogurt. While waiting for my breakfast my daughter went done to the lobby for "good" coffee as I walked the halls (totally mile before breakfast and another mile after breakfast). Lunch and dinner were both a full meal (with stewed prunes and yogurt ... my choice to help stay "regular" and to but some good probiotics back into me. Guess the bottom line is what your doc says you and or can not eat.

Posts.Title: Two Year Update

Posts.Content: Lake ... by all accounts I am too a new guy to all this (see my signature below for details). We too (wife and I) considered all the options such as the radiation et al knowing that the long term results were probably ending up the same. For us, we need to know first hand nitty gritty what we are dealing with and the surgery would answer that question for us. The other consideration for us was knowing if the surgery did not get it all out (which it did not) we still had the option to go back to radiation to hopefully clean things up. Please know this is our personal decision and may not be the best decision for someone else ... it is all a personal decision we all must make. If there we other deciding factors we could of possibly opted for the radiation route instead of surgery.

Posts.Content: nmguy: same with me. I get up about every two hours to pee too. Pretty good healthy pees. Then again, we are on a European eating habit in this house with four meals per day ... our largest meal is at 7:30p in the evening. I have at least a pint of water eating the late meal with another half pint of water taking supplements and such before bedtime (usually 9 to 9:30P). Probably reason I have to pee at night. I wear the diapers day and night but they usually wear out coming apart and not from getting wet. I wear the diaper as a backup redundant type system in-case the pads don't do their jobs. Probably should just wear skivvies during the day with the pads and use the diapers and pads at night to protect the bed. Since I am dry at night, I get the old school feeling to pee instead of leaking.

My answer is that I think so, no more biopsies but I am not sure since I do not know if the surgery removes the entire prostate or just the cancerous portion.

Posts.Title: Margins?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dave&Barb Best wishes to those of you going thru or facing possible ART/salvage RT, hang in there, that light at the end of the tunnel will get bright before you know it. Few tips that worked for Dave: 9am appt time worked best for him as it gave him plenty of time to have empty colon and full bladder. Full bladder was uncomfortable, but we found that NO caffeine helped, as well as wearing pants with loose waistband. Earlier and smaller suppers with easier to digest stuff, light on veggies and fiber. He got sent home just one day because of non-empty colon, so he made sure that didn't happen again. He also said it was helpful having me go each time so he didn't have to stress about driving and parking. Great to hear ... and appreciate the tips as I am sure this will be one of the paths I will be going down.

Posts.Title: Gonna take all the good news I can ...

Posts.Content: Guess I am impatient. Am just over two weeks post catheter removal. My first week I averaged 3 pads/1 diaper per day ... then second week 4 pads/no diapers per day with the exception on day went through 7 pads. I try to do my kegels everyday but some days forget. The second week I went back to my part time retirement job with only walking and getting in and out of the truck with no lifting (have a great boss who is riding herd on me to take it easy). I stay at night walking and sleeping, I do leak when getting up from a seated position or coughing/sneezing/ farting. Also found myself leaking when a little agitated with the NCAA basketball game and doing taxes. Seems I read somewhere here that other guys were averaging 10 to 12 pads per day so guess I am doing pretty good considering.

Posts.Title: Good TED talk

Posts.Content: Quick introduction: Biopsy week ago, results 24 hours ago. Everything is a bit of a blur and working on getting a handle of things today. Researching, ordering books, making doc appointments, scheduling bone and CT scans as well as adding my five-year colonoscopy follow-up. Found this forum today and just signed up. Biopsy diagnosis: 13 samples, (6) Gleason score 7, (2) Gleason score 8, (4) Gleason score 9 and (1) suspicious. Staging is 3. CT in 2016 (little blood and stones due to dehydration working outside in extreme heat) and MRI Dec 2018 show prostate normal size with no enlargement (comparing the 2016 CT to the 2018 MRI). PSA Nov 2018 7.1 Prescribed Proscar and Flomax PSA Dec 2018 4.1 (PSA drop due to Proscar ?) Yesterday, off of Proscar and Flomax. Age 63. Still coming to terms with all this.
Posts.Title: Recent Diagnosis ... New Member

Posts.Content: Oh dang ... everything I wrote disappeared when I clicked on the wrong button. In short, yes know I am high risk and have appts setup with different doctors to determine my care as well as have scheduled my bone and CT scans. Felt like I got a lot done in the first 24 hours. Understand the pitfalls of information on the internet so I take that all with a grain of salt. My diet has been good but now told to stop red meat and go mainly veggie with occasional wild salmon. I feel good with no aches or pains and am looking for the snow/ice to be gone so I can get out and run (mostly likely next week). Obviously I am having some emotional anxiety but that is to be expected. I have a good support system. Thanks for reaching out Duck 2 !

Posts.Title: Recent Diagnosis ... New Member

Posts.Content: Thanks guys, means a lot to hear from you all. Yeah, it is "surreal" and I have been "uncertain, frustrated, confused, and even angry". Though I feel this way I am wired to be able to set all that aside for a while as I take care of my health plans ... but then when things slow down I find myself on that roller-coaster again. As I now enter day 2 post DX (hey, my first abbreviation) my lingering question is deciding on the doctor(s) and/or facility I will be going for treating. My bone and CT scan are on Feb 19th and I figure those results with determine that best course of treatment to follow. At least I am retired, with a little local part time job that is flexible, so that gets me out of the house. I think for my future posts/questions I will open a new thread with a related title ... and will include a link in my signature to this introduction. In the next couple of days I will set up my signature with my historical results as you guys have done. I am glad I found this forum, thanks.

Posts.Content: Thanks Michael F and Bab. Learned there is 6 to 8 weeks out from the biopsy before doing anything to let the prostate calm down. Am using every bit I time in the process to get my ducks in line ... been more like herding cats. Today got my colonoscopy scheduled for next week (my five-year is coming up and the URO thought may as well do it now instead of later. Not my first rodeo with this so know what to expect. My Dr Walsh 2018v book arrives tomorrow, looking forward to see what was updated from the 2012v. Agree with the one good opportunity to do it right. This is where I am stumbling around regarding what doc and where. Since I really need some thoughts on this I will let you all know that I am in the Seattle area. Lots of different medical facilities around here such as Seattle Cancer Care Alliance, University of Washington Medical Center, Swedish and Virginia Mason. Appreciate any thoughts. Bab ... great metaphor, gave me a chuckle, I needed that. And, I do not mind being second place to you for that "honor". Update: I just posted my first thread with a specific question. https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...404#post377404
